1.name: Precentral_L
structure: Primary motor cortex (M1) located on the precentral gyrus of the left frontal lobe, anterior to the central sulcus
Contains giant pyramidal cells of Betz in layer V that form the corticospinal tract
Organized somatotopically with an inverted homunculus representation (legs superior, face inferior)
Receives input from premotor cortex, supplementary motor area, thalamus, and somatosensory cortex
function: Controls voluntary movement execution for the right side of the body
Encodes movement parameters including direction, force, and speed
Forms direct monosynaptic connections with spinal motor neurons via corticospinal tract
Damage results in contralateral hemiplegia/hemiparesis with characteristic upper motor neuron signs

2.name: Precentral_R
structure: Primary motor cortex located on the precentral gyrus of the right frontal lobe
Exhibits identical cytoarchitecture to the left with Betz cells in layer V
Somatotopically organized with regions controlling face, upper limb, and lower limb
Connected to contralateral motor cortex via corpus callosum and ipsilateral subcortical motor structures
function: Controls voluntary movement execution for the left side of the body
Integrates sensory feedback to modify ongoing movements
Coordinates with supplementary motor area and premotor cortex to plan complex movements
Damage results in left-sided weakness/paralysis with hyperreflexia and Babinski sign

3.name: Frontal_Sup_L
structure: Superior portion of the left frontal lobe corresponding to Brodmann areas 8, 9, and 10
Located dorsal to middle frontal gyrus and anterior to precentral gyrus
Contains primarily association cortex with extensive connections to other prefrontal regions
Shows greater density of neurons involved in language processing compared to right hemisphere
function: Involved in higher cognitive functions including working memory, attention, and executive control
Participates in planning and coordinating complex behavioral sequences
Contributes to verbal working memory and semantic processing
Damage may result in executive dysfunction, attention deficits, and personality changes

4.name: Frontal_Sup_R
structure: Superior portion of the right frontal lobe corresponding to Brodmann areas 8, 9, and 10
Cytoarchitecturally similar to left superior frontal gyrus but with functional specialization
Contains high density of connections with parietal attentional networks
Shows particular development of regions involved in spatial working memory
function: Specialized for spatial working memory and visuospatial attention
Contributes to inhibitory control and cognitive flexibility
Involved in social cognition including theory of mind and perspective-taking
Lesions associated with impaired sustained attention and spatial working memory deficits

5.name: Frontal_Sup_Orb_L
structure: Orbital (ventral) portion of the left superior frontal gyrus
Located in the frontal pole and medial orbital surface
Rich connections with limbic structures including amygdala and anterior cingulate
Contains von Economo neurons associated with social cognition
function: Involved in emotion regulation and social decision-making
Contributes to reward valuation and goal-directed behavior
Participates in personality expression and appropriate social conduct
Damage associated with disinhibition, poor judgment, and emotional dysregulation

6.name: Frontal_Sup_Orb_R
structure: Orbital (ventral) portion of the right superior frontal gyrus
Contains high density of connections with autonomic regulatory centers
Extensively connected with insular cortex and limbic structures
Shows functional specialization for processing negative emotional stimuli
function: Critical for monitoring and regulation of emotional states
Involved in processing negative affective information and risk assessment
Contributes to impulse control and inhibition of inappropriate behaviors
Lesions associated with personality changes including apathy or disinhibition

7.name: Frontal_Mid_L
structure: Middle portion of the left frontal gyrus containing parts of Brodmann areas 6, 8, 9, and 46
Contains dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, a key region for executive function
Shows extensive reciprocal connections with parietal cortex and subcortical structures
Higher density of neurons involved in verbal working memory compared to right hemisphere
function: Critical for working memory maintenance and manipulation, especially for verbal information
Involved in cognitive control, including task switching and conflict resolution
Participates in language planning and verbal fluency
Dysfunction associated with executive deficits in schizophrenia and other psychiatric disorders

8.name: Frontal_Mid_R
structure: Middle portion of the right frontal gyrus containing parts of Brodmann areas 6, 8, 9, and 46
Contains key regions of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex
Shows extensive connectivity with visuospatial processing networks
Structural asymmetries compared to left counterpart related to functional specialization
function: Specialized for spatial working memory and nonverbal executive functions
Involved in attentional control, particularly sustained and selective attention
Contributes to response inhibition and cognitive flexibility
Lesions associated with impaired problem-solving, mental flexibility, and spatial working memory

9.name: Frontal_Mid_Orb_L
structure: Orbital (ventral) portion of the left middle frontal gyrus
Located in the ventrolateral prefrontal cortex
Rich connections with limbic structures and basal ganglia
Contains neurons responsive to reward-related stimuli
function: Involved in reward processing and incentive motivation
Contributes to decision-making based on reward contingencies
Participates in emotional regulation and impulse control
Dysfunction implicated in addiction, compulsive behaviors, and mood disorders

10.name: Frontal_Mid_Orb_R
structure: Orbital (ventral) portion of the right middle frontal gyrus
Contains high density of connections with insular cortex
Shows functional specialization for processing emotional and social information
Extensively connected with autonomic regulatory centers
function: Critical for integrating emotional information into decision-making
Involved in risk assessment and evaluation of negative consequences
Contributes to social cognition and interpretation of social cues
Lesions associated with risk-taking behavior and poor social judgment

11.name: Frontal_Inf_Oper_L
structure: Opercular (posterior) part of the left inferior frontal gyrus, corresponding to Brodmann area 44
Forms part of the classical Broca's area for language production
Contains specialized neurons for processing syntactic information
Structurally connected to superior temporal regions via arcuate fasciculus
function: Critical for syntactic processing and grammatical aspects of language
Involved in phonological processing and speech articulation
Contributes to verbal working memory and sequence processing
Damage results in Broca's aphasia characterized by non-fluent, agrammatic speech

12.name: Frontal_Inf_Oper_R
structure: Opercular (posterior) part of the right inferior frontal gyrus, corresponding to Brodmann area 44
Homologous to left Broca's area but with functional specialization
Shows activation during prosodic and emotional aspects of language
Connected to right superior temporal regions via arcuate fasciculus
function: Processes prosodic and emotional aspects of language
Involved in musical syntax and rhythm processing
Contributes to inhibitory control in non-linguistic domains
Lesions may impair emotional prosody while preserving propositional language

13.name: Frontal_Inf_Tri_L
structure: Triangular part of the left inferior frontal gyrus, corresponding to Brodmann area 45
Forms anterior portion of classical Broca's area
Contains neurons specialized for semantic processing
Extensively connected with temporal and parietal language areas
function: Critical for semantic processing and lexical retrieval
Involved in controlled semantic selection and integration
Participates in verbal fluency and word generation
Damage contributes to semantic deficits in aphasia syndromes

14.name: Frontal_Inf_Tri_R
structure: Triangular part of the right inferior frontal gyrus, corresponding to Brodmann area 45
Homologous to left area 45 but with functional specialization
Shows activation during figurative language processing
Connected with right temporal regions involved in pragmatic aspects of communication
function: Involved in processing metaphors, idioms, and indirect speech
Contributes to understanding humor and sarcasm
Participates in social language and pragmatic inference
Lesions may impair understanding of non-literal language while preserving literal comprehension

15.name: Frontal_Inf_Orb_L
structure: Orbital part of the left inferior frontal gyrus, corresponding to Brodmann area 47
Contains ventrolateral prefrontal cortex regions
Extensive connections with temporal lobe and limbic structures
Shows dense connectivity with basal ganglia circuits
function: Involved in semantic aspects of language processing
Critical for selection among competing semantic alternatives
Contributes to inhibitory control in verbal domains
Dysfunction associated with perseveration and semantic confusions

16.name: Frontal_Inf_Orb_R
structure: Orbital part of the right inferior frontal gyrus, corresponding to Brodmann area 47
Shows enhanced connectivity with limbic structures compared to left counterpart
Contains neurons responsive to social and emotional stimuli
Extensively connected with right temporal pole
function: Involved in processing emotional prosody and tone of voice
Contributes to response inhibition and cognitive control
Participates in social cognition and evaluation of social cues
Lesions associated with impaired emotional regulation and social judgment

17.name: Rolandic_Oper_L
structure: Left opercular region near the inferior end of the central sulcus (Rolandic fissure)
Contains parts of primary sensorimotor cortex for the face, tongue, and larynx
Includes portions of Brodmann areas 43 and adjacent areas
Connected to subcortical structures involved in articulatory control
function: Critical for speech articulation and phonological processing
Involved in sensorimotor integration for the orofacial region
Contributes to the production and perception of speech sounds
Lesions result in dysarthria and speech apraxia

18.name: Rolandic_Oper_R
structure: Right opercular region near the inferior end of the central sulcus
Contains sensorimotor cortex for the face region
Shows activation during vocalization and prosodic processing
Connected with limbic structures involved in emotional expression
function: Involved in prosodic and emotional aspects of speech production
Contributes to sensorimotor control of the left side of the face
Participates in non-verbal vocal expression (laughter, crying)
Lesions may result in aprosodia while preserving basic articulation

19.name: Supp_Motor_Area_L
structure: Left supplementary motor area located on the medial surface of the frontal lobe, corresponding to medial Brodmann area 6
Contains somatotopically organized motor maps with bilateral representation
Densely connected with primary motor cortex, basal ganglia, and spinal cord
Shows dense connectivity with language areas in left hemisphere
function: Critical for planning and initiation of complex movement sequences
Involved in bimanual coordination and movement timing
Contributes to speech initiation and motor aspects of language
Lesions result in transient mutism, difficulty initiating movements, and alien hand syndrome

20.name: Supp_Motor_Area_R
structure: Right supplementary motor area located on the medial surface of the frontal lobe
Contains somatotopically organized motor maps with bilateral representation
Connected with right primary motor cortex and subcortical motor structures
Shows increased activation during spatial motor planning
function: Critical for planning and coordination of movements, particularly on the left side of the body
Involved in suppression of unwanted movements and response inhibition
Contributes to sequential organization of complex motor acts
Lesions may result in akinesia, deficits in motor planning, and alien hand syndrome

21.name: Olfactory_L
structure: Left olfactory cortex located on the orbital surface of the frontal lobe
Includes primary olfactory cortex (piriform cortex) and closely related structures
Receives direct input from olfactory bulb via cranial nerve I
Extensive connections with limbic structures including amygdala and hippocampus
function: Processes and discriminates odors arriving from the right nostril
Involved in odor identification and emotional responses to smells
Contributes to formation of olfactory memories with strong emotional components
Dysfunction may result in specific anosmia or olfactory hallucinations

22.name: Olfactory_R
structure: Right olfactory cortex including piriform cortex and related structures
Receives direct projections from right olfactory bulb
Shows strong connectivity with right amygdala and hippocampus
Contains neurons responding to specific odor molecules
function: Processes and discriminates odors arriving from the left nostril
Participates in automatic emotional responses to odors
Contributes to implicit olfactory memory and odor recognition
Dysfunction associated with qualitative distortions in smell perception

23.name: Frontal_Sup_Medial_L
structure: Medial portion of the left superior frontal gyrus, including parts of Brodmann areas 8, 9, and 10
Located on the medial surface of the frontal lobe superior to the cingulate gyrus
Contains regions involved in Theory of Mind and self-referential processing
Dense connections with anterior cingulate and other medial prefrontal regions
function: Critical for social cognition and understanding others' mental states
Involved in self-referential processing and introspection
Contributes to motivation and goal-directed behaviors
Lesions associated with apathy, reduced spontaneity, and impaired social cognition

24.name: Frontal_Sup_Medial_R
structure: Medial portion of the right superior frontal gyrus
Contains nodes of the default mode network
Shows activation during mentalization and social cognition tasks
Connected with limbic structures involved in emotional processing
function: Specialized for emotional aspects of social cognition
Involved in processing non-verbal social cues and emotional states
Contributes to self-awareness and autobiographical memory
Dysfunction associated with impaired emotional understanding and social interaction

25.name: Frontal_Med_Orb_L
structure: Medial orbital region of left frontal lobe, including ventromedial prefrontal cortex
Contains Brodmann areas 11, 12, and portions of 10
Rich connections with limbic structures and hypothalamus
Contains neurons responsive to reward value and emotional significance
function: Critical for value-based decision making and emotional regulation
Involved in representing anticipated rewards and punishment outcomes
Contributes to regulation of autonomic and emotional responses
Damage associated with impaired decision-making, as in the Iowa Gambling Task

26.name: Frontal_Med_Orb_R
structure: Medial orbital region of right frontal lobe, including ventromedial prefrontal cortex
Shows high metabolic activity at rest as part of default mode network
Extensive connections with autonomic regulatory centers
Contains specialized neurons for processing emotional and social information
function: Integrates emotional information into decision-making processes
Involved in moral reasoning and social norm processing
Contributes to regulation of fear and anxiety responses
Lesions associated with sociopathic behavior and impaired moral judgment

27.name: Rectus_L
structure: Left gyrus rectus (straight gyrus) on the orbital surface of the frontal lobe
Corresponds to medial portion of Brodmann area 11
Contains high density of serotonin and dopamine receptors
Connected with limbic structures and hypothalamus
function: Involved in reward processing and hedonic evaluation
Contributes to mood regulation and affective responses
Participates in drive states and motivated behavior
Dysfunction implicated in mood disorders and addiction

28.name: Rectus_R
structure: Right gyrus rectus on the orbital surface of the frontal lobe
Shows hemispheric specialization for processing negatively valenced emotional stimuli
Contains neurons responsive to emotionally salient stimuli
Connected with hypothalamic centers regulating autonomic responses
function: Processes negative emotional valence and aversive stimuli
Involved in regulation of emotional responses to environmental cues
Contributes to visceral and autonomic aspects of emotional processing
Lesions associated with emotional blunting and impaired emotional learning

29.name: Insula_L
structure: Left insular cortex located deep within the Sylvian fissure
Divided into anterior agranular and posterior granular portions
Contains Von Economo neurons in anterior portion
Extensive connections with limbic, paralimbic, and frontal opercular regions
function: Processes interoceptive information, including visceral sensations, pain, and temperature
Critical for awareness of emotional states and the embodied self
Involved in empathy, disgust recognition, and taste perception
Dysfunction implicated in anxiety disorders, addiction, and somatoform disorders

30.name: Insula_R
structure: Right insular cortex with distinct anterior and posterior divisions
Shows enhanced activation during interoceptive attention and emotional awareness
Contains specialized neurons for processing bodily sensations
Connected with autonomic regulatory centers in brainstem
function: Specialized for processing bodily sensations related to emotional states
Involved in sympathetic arousal and cardiovascular regulation
Contributes to risk assessment and emotional decision-making
Lesions may result in anosognosia and impaired emotional awareness

31.name: Cingulum_Ant_L
structure: Anterior portion of the left cingulate gyrus corresponding to Brodmann areas 24, 32, and 33
Forms part of the limbic system on the medial surface of the hemisphere
Contains agranular cortex with distinct connections to frontal regions
Dense dopaminergic innervation and high concentration of opioid receptors
function: Critical for cognitive control, error detection, and conflict monitoring
Involved in attention allocation and task engagement
Contributes to motivation and reward-based learning
Dysfunction implicated in attention deficit disorder, OCD, and depression

32.name: Cingulum_Ant_R
structure: Anterior portion of the right cingulate gyrus
Shows functional specialization for emotional regulation and autonomic control
Contains neurons sensitive to negative emotional states
Extensively connected with right prefrontal regions
function: Specialized for emotional aspects of cognitive control
Involved in autonomic regulation during emotional processing
Contributes to emotional awareness and assessment of emotional significance
Lesions associated with apathy, emotional blunting, and impaired emotional regulation

33.name: Cingulum_Mid_L
structure: Middle portion of the left cingulate gyrus corresponding to Brodmann area 24
Contains distinct cingulate motor areas with somatotopic organization
Connected with supplementary motor area and premotor cortex
Receives nociceptive input from thalamus
function: Involved in response selection and motor control
Processes pain affect and contributes to pain modulation
Participates in awareness of voluntariness of actions
Dysfunction implicated in chronic pain syndromes and motor conversion disorders

34.name: Cingulum_Mid_R
structure: Middle portion of the right cingulate gyrus
Contains neurons responsive to painful stimuli
Shows functional connectivity with pain processing networks
Connected with right motor and premotor regions
function: Processes emotional aspects of pain experience
Involved in autonomic responses to pain and stress
Contributes to motivation and effort allocation
Lesions associated with pain asymbolia (recognition without emotional response)

35.name: Cingulum_Post_L
structure: Posterior portion of the left cingulate gyrus corresponding to Brodmann areas 23 and 31
Forms part of the posterior medial cortex
Contains granular cortex with extensive connections to parietal regions
Key node in the default mode network
function: Critical for episodic memory retrieval and autobiographical memory
Involved in visuospatial cognition and navigation
Contributes to self-referential processing and internal mentation
Dysfunction associated with memory impairment and disorientation

36.name: Cingulum_Post_R
structure: Posterior portion of the right cingulate gyrus
Shows high metabolic activity during rest as part of default mode network
Connected with right medial temporal and parietal regions
Contains neurons activated during spatial navigation and memory tasks
function: Specialized for spatial aspects of autobiographical memory
Involved in scene construction and visual imagery
Contributes to spatial navigation and environmental memory
Lesions may result in topographical disorientation while preserving other memory functions

37.name: Hippocampus_L
structure: Left hippocampal formation in the medial temporal lobe
Consists of distinct subfields: CA1, CA2, CA3, CA4, dentate gyrus, and subiculum
Contains unique trisynaptic circuit (perforant path → dentate → CA3 → CA1)
Shows hemispheric specialization for verbal memory
function: Critical for episodic memory formation and declarative memory
Specialized for verbal and semantic memory in left hemisphere
Facilitates memory consolidation through replay during sleep
Damage results in anterograde amnesia and impaired verbal memory

38.name: Hippocampus_R
structure: Right hippocampal formation in the medial temporal lobe
Contains identical cellular architecture to left hippocampus
Shows functional specialization for spatial and visual memory
Contains specialized place cells that fire when animal is in specific locations
function: Critical for spatial navigation and environmental memory
Specialized for visuospatial memory and pattern recognition
Contributes to emotional memory with emphasis on spatial context
Damage results in topographical disorientation and spatial memory deficits

39.name: ParaHippocampal_L
structure: Left parahippocampal gyrus located in medial temporal lobe
Includes entorhinal cortex (Brodmann area 28) and perirhinal cortex
Serves as major input/output pathway for hippocampus
Contains neurons responsive to complex visual scenes and spatial configurations
function: Critical for contextual associations and memory encoding
Involved in semantic processing and verbal memory
Serves as gateway between neocortex and hippocampus
Lesions result in associative memory deficits and semantic impairment

40.name: ParaHippocampal_R
structure: Right parahippocampal gyrus in the medial temporal lobe
Contains parahippocampal place area specialized for scene recognition
Extensively connected with visual association areas
Shows greater activation during spatial navigation tasks
function: Specialized for processing spatial layouts and scenes
Critical for encoding and recognition of landmarks
Contributes to context-dependent memory with emphasis on spatial features
Lesions result in landmark agnosia and topographical disorientation

41.name: Amygdala_L
structure: Left amygdala located in the anterior medial temporal lobe
Consists of basolateral, centromedial, and cortical nuclear groups
Extensively connected with hypothalamus, prefrontal cortex, and sensory systems
Shows hemispheric specialization for language-based emotional processing
function: Critical for fear conditioning and threat detection
Involved in emotional memory enhancement, especially for verbal material
Mediates autonomic responses to emotional stimuli
Dysfunction implicated in anxiety disorders, PTSD, and mood disorders

42.name: Amygdala_R
structure: Right amygdala in the anterior medial temporal lobe
Contains identical nuclear divisions to left amygdala
Shows specialization for processing emotionally salient visual stimuli
Extensively connected with visual processing streams
function: Specialized for processing emotional facial expressions and visual emotional stimuli
Involved in rapid, automatic threat detection
Contributes to emotional modulation of memory with emphasis on visual material
Lesions result in impaired recognition of emotional expressions while preserving ability to identify faces

43.name: Calcarine_L
structure: Left calcarine sulcus containing primary visual cortex (V1, Brodmann area 17)
Located in the medial occipital lobe surrounding the calcarine fissure
Contains distinct layer IV with stria of Gennari visible macroscopically
Organized retinotopically with foveal representation at occipital pole
function: Processes basic visual information from right visual field
Performs primary analysis of visual features including orientation, spatial frequency, and color
Implements early visual processing including edge detection and contrast enhancement
Lesions result in right homonymous hemianopia or quadrantanopia

44.name: Calcarine_R
structure: Right calcarine sulcus containing primary visual cortex
Organized retinotopically with macular representation at posterior end
Contains columnar organization for orientation selectivity
Receives input from left visual field via optic radiations
function: Processes basic visual information from left visual field
Extracts elementary visual features including lines, edges, and contrast
Performs parallel processing of multiple visual attributes
Lesions result in left homonymous hemianopia or quadrantanopia

45.name: Cuneus_L
structure: Left cuneus located on the medial surface of the occipital lobe above the calcarine sulcus
Contains parts of primary visual cortex (V1) and secondary visual areas (V2, V3)
Organized retinotopically with representation of peripheral visual field
Connected with adjacent visual areas via vertical connections
function: Processes visual information from lower right visual field
Involved in basic visual processing and early visual integration
Contributes to visual attention and saccadic eye movements
Lesions result in right lower quadrantanopia

46.name: Cuneus_R
structure: Right cuneus located on the medial surface of the occipital lobe above the calcarine sulcus
Contains parts of primary visual cortex (V1) and secondary visual areas (V2, V3)
Organized retinotopically with representation of peripheral visual field
Connected with adjacent visual areas via vertical and horizontal connections
function: Processes visual information from lower left visual field
Involved in basic visual processing and early visual integration
Contributes to visual attention and saccadic eye movements
Lesions result in left lower quadrantanopia

47.name: Lingual_L
structure: Left lingual gyrus located on the medial surface of the occipital lobe below the calcarine sulcus
Extends anteriorly from the occipital pole to the parahippocampal gyrus
Contains portions of V1, V2, and V3 visual processing areas
Rich in connections with adjacent visual areas and ventral visual stream
function: Processes visual information from upper right visual field
Critical for processing visual features including color and form recognition
Involved in visual memory encoding and dream imagery
Contributes to reading processes and letter recognition

48.name: Lingual_R
structure: Right lingual gyrus located on the medial surface of the occipital lobe below the calcarine sulcus
Extends anteriorly from the occipital pole to the parahippocampal gyrus
Contains portions of V1, V2, and V3 visual processing areas
Forms part of the ventral visual processing stream
function: Processes visual information from upper left visual field
Important for visual feature analysis including color discrimination
Contributes to global scene recognition and visual context processing
Lesions may result in left upper quadrantanopia or achromatopsia

49.name: Occipital_Sup_L
structure: Left superior occipital gyrus located on the lateral and superior aspect of the occipital lobe
Contains extrastriate visual areas including V2 and V3
Connected to dorsal visual stream structures and parietal cortices
Organized retinotopically with central vision represented anteriorly
function: Processes higher-order visual information from right visual field
Contributes to visuospatial attention and visual feature binding
Involved in visual motion perception and spatial navigation
Integrates visual information for object location and motion tracking

50.name: Occipital_Sup_R
structure: Right superior occipital gyrus located on the lateral and superior aspect of the occipital lobe
Contains extrastriate visual areas including V2 and V3
Connected to dorsal visual stream structures and parietal cortices
Receives feedforward projections from primary visual cortex
function: Processes higher-order visual information from left visual field
Contributes to visuospatial attention and visual feature integration
Important for spatial vision and detection of motion in the environment
Participates in visual search and attentional allocation

51.name: Occipital_Mid_L
structure: Left middle occipital gyrus located on the lateral surface of the occipital lobe
Contains visual area V5/MT and other extrastriate regions
Bridges ventral and dorsal visual processing streams
Rich in connections with temporal and parietal visual areas
function: Specialized for visual motion detection and analysis in right visual field
Contributes to object recognition and visual form processing
Involved in spatial attention and visuomotor coordination
Important for perception of biological motion and action understanding

52.name: Occipital_Mid_R
structure: Right middle occipital gyrus located on the lateral surface of the occipital lobe
Contains visual area V5/MT and other extrastriate regions
Forms part of both dorsal and ventral visual processing streams
Highly developed in humans compared to non-human primates
function: Specialized for visual motion detection and analysis in left visual field
Contributes to visual form analysis and object discrimination
Important for spatial attention and visual search behaviors
Processes global visual patterns and complex motion patterns

53.name: Occipital_Inf_L
structure: Left inferior occipital gyrus located on the inferior lateral surface of the occipital lobe
Contains higher visual areas including parts of V3 and V4
Forms part of the ventral visual stream for object recognition
Connected to inferior temporal regions involved in visual processing
function: Processes complex visual features from right visual field
Involved in color perception and processing
Contributes to object identification and visual form analysis
Important for visual categorization and perceptual learning

54.name: Occipital_Inf_R
structure: Right inferior occipital gyrus located on the inferior lateral surface of the occipital lobe
Contains higher visual areas including parts of V3 and V4
Forms part of the ventral visual stream for object recognition
Projects anteriorly to temporal lobe visual areas
function: Processes complex visual features from left visual field
Important for color discrimination and processing
Contributes to object recognition and form analysis
Involved in visual categorization and face processing

55.name: Fusiform_L
structure: Left fusiform gyrus located on the ventral surface of the temporal and occipital lobes
Contains specialized regions including the fusiform face area (FFA) and visual word form area (VWFA)
Forms a central component of the ventral visual stream
Rich in connections with hippocampus and parahippocampal regions
function: Critical for face recognition and facial expression processing
Specialized for visual word form recognition and reading
Involved in expert visual categorization and visual memory
Contributes to color processing and multisensory integration

56.name: Fusiform_R
structure: Right fusiform gyrus located on the ventral surface of the temporal and occipital lobes
Contains the fusiform face area (FFA) specialized for face processing
Forms a central component of the ventral visual stream
Connected to amygdala and other limbic structures for emotional processing
function: Dominant hemisphere for face recognition and facial identity processing
Involved in processing emotional facial expressions
Contributes to visual expertise for non-facial stimuli
Important for visual object categorization and recognition

57.name: Postcentral_L
structure: Left postcentral gyrus located posterior to the central sulcus in the parietal lobe
Contains primary somatosensory cortex (Brodmann areas 1, 2, and 3)
Organized somatotopically with the face inferior, trunk central, and legs superior
Six distinct cortical layers with specialized cellular organization
function: Processes somatosensory input from the right side of the body
Responsible for tactile discrimination, proprioception, and temperature sensation
Processes touch, pressure, vibration, and pain sensations
Critical for stereognosis and fine tactile discrimination

58.name: Postcentral_R
structure: Right postcentral gyrus located posterior to the central sulcus in the parietal lobe
Contains primary somatosensory cortex (Brodmann areas 1, 2, and 3)
Organized somatotopically with inverted body representation (sensory homunculus)
Receives projections from ventral posterior nucleus of the thalamus
function: Processes somatosensory input from the left side of the body
Responsible for tactile discrimination, proprioception, and kinesthesia
Interprets texture, shape, and size of objects through touch
Lesions may cause contralateral hemihypesthesia or astereognosis

59.name: Parietal_Sup_L
structure: Left superior parietal lobule located posterior to the postcentral gyrus above the intraparietal sulcus
Contains Brodmann areas 5 and 7
Connected to premotor areas, prefrontal cortex, and occipital visual areas
Rich in connections with dorsal visual stream structures
function: Integrates somatosensory and visual information for spatial awareness
Critical for visuomotor coordination and reaching movements
Involved in spatial attention and mental rotation tasks
Important for interpreting spatial relationships and body schema

60.name: Parietal_Sup_R
structure: Right superior parietal lobule located posterior to the postcentral gyrus above the intraparietal sulcus
Contains Brodmann areas 5 and 7
Connected to premotor areas, prefrontal cortex, and occipital visual areas
Forms part of the dorsal visual stream ('where/how' pathway)
function: Dominant hemisphere for visuospatial processing and attention
Critical for mental imagery and spatial navigation
Contributes to eye-hand coordination and reaching movements
Involved in global attention and awareness of extrapersonal space

61.name: Parietal_Inf_L
structure: Left inferior parietal lobule located below the intraparietal sulcus
Contains the supramarginal and angular gyri (Brodmann areas 39 and 40)
Connected to language areas in left temporal and frontal lobes
Forms part of the dorsal visual stream with extensive frontoparietal connections
function: Critical for language processing, particularly phonological aspects
Involved in arithmetic calculation and numerical processing
Important for tool use understanding and praxis
Contributes to working memory and executive functions

62.name: Parietal_Inf_R
structure: Right inferior parietal lobule located below the intraparietal sulcus
Contains the supramarginal and angular gyri (Brodmann areas 39 and 40)
Connected to attentional networks and visuospatial processing regions
Rich in connections with visual association areas
function: Dominant for visuospatial attention and neglect syndromes when damaged
Important for body schema and self-awareness
Contributes to emotion recognition and social cognition
Involved in non-verbal aspects of communication and prosody

63.name: SupraMarginal_L
structure: Left supramarginal gyrus forms anterior part of the inferior parietal lobule
Contains Brodmann area 40
Connected to auditory areas, Wernicke's area, and motor regions
Wraps around the posterior end of the lateral sulcus
function: Critical for phonological processing and word reading
Important for verbal working memory and short-term verbal storage
Central to language comprehension and articulation
Involved in gesture recognition and praxis

64.name: SupraMarginal_R
structure: Right supramarginal gyrus forms anterior part of the inferior parietal lobule
Contains Brodmann area 40
Connected to sensorimotor integration circuits and attentional networks
Forms part of the mirror neuron system
function: Involved in spatial attention and visuospatial processing
Contributes to emotional processing and empathy
Important for recognition of emotions from facial expressions
Participates in integration of tactile and proprioceptive information

65.name: Angular_L
structure: Left angular gyrus forms posterior part of the inferior parietal lobule
Contains Brodmann area 39
Connected to visual, auditory, and language processing regions
Located at the junction of temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes
function: Critical for semantic processing and language comprehension
Essential for reading comprehension and word meaning
Involved in complex language functions including metaphor understanding
Contributes to arithmetic operations and mathematical reasoning

66.name: Angular_R
structure: Right angular gyrus forms posterior part of the inferior parietal lobule
Contains Brodmann area 39
Connected to attentional networks and visual association areas
Located at the junction of temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes
function: Important for visuospatial attention and spatial cognition
Contributes to processing of emotional context and social cues
Involved in theory of mind and perspective-taking abilities
Participates in episodic memory retrieval and mental imagery

67.name: Precuneus_L
structure: Left precuneus located on the medial surface of the parietal lobe
Contains Brodmann area 7 medial section
Connected extensively to thalamus, posterior cingulate, and prefrontal regions
Forms core component of the default mode network
function: Central to episodic memory retrieval and autobiographical memory
Involved in self-referential processing and consciousness
Contributes to visuospatial imagery and mental navigation
Important for attention shifting between different spatial locations

68.name: Precuneus_R
structure: Right precuneus located on the medial surface of the parietal lobe
Contains Brodmann area 7 medial section
Connected extensively to thalamus, posterior cingulate, and prefrontal regions
Higher metabolic activity at rest than most brain regions
function: Central to episodic memory retrieval and spatial memory
Important for self-consciousness and first-person perspective
Contributes to mental imagery and visualization
Involved in visuospatial processing and navigation

69.name: Paracentral_Lobule_L
structure: Left paracentral lobule located on the medial surface extending from precentral to postcentral gyri
Contains primary motor and sensory representations for the lower limb
Includes portions of Brodmann areas 1, 2, 3, 4, and 6
Connected to supplementary motor area and medial premotor regions
function: Controls voluntary movement of the right foot and leg
Processes sensory information from the right lower limb
Crucial for control of micturition and defecation
Important for coordinated locomotion and gait

70.name: Paracentral_Lobule_R
structure: Right paracentral lobule located on the medial surface extending from precentral to postcentral gyri
Contains primary motor and sensory representations for the lower limb
Includes portions of Brodmann areas 1, 2, 3, 4, and 6
Connected to deeper motor structures and central pattern generators
function: Controls voluntary movement of the left foot and leg
Processes sensory information from the left lower limb
Critical for bladder and bowel control
Involved in execution of complex lower limb movements

71.name: Caudate_L
structure: Left caudate nucleus, a C-shaped structure forming part of the dorsal striatum
Divided into head (anterior), body (middle), and tail (posterior) segments
Receives glutamatergic inputs from cortex and dopaminergic inputs from substantia nigra
Connected extensively to prefrontal cortical areas and thalamus
function: Critical component of cognitive and limbic basal ganglia circuits
Involved in goal-directed behaviors and action selection
Important for procedural learning and habit formation
Contributes to executive functions including cognitive flexibility

72.name: Caudate_R
structure: Right caudate nucleus, a C-shaped structure forming part of the dorsal striatum
Divided into head (adjacent to lateral ventricle), body, and tail segments
Rich in medium spiny neurons containing GABA and neuropeptides
Forms part of cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical circuits
function: Involved in reward processing and reinforcement learning
Contributes to cognitive control and inhibition of inappropriate responses
Important for procedural memory and sequence learning
Implicated in attention regulation and working memory

73.name: Putamen_L
structure: Left putamen, a rounded structure forming lateral part of the lentiform nucleus
Located lateral to the internal capsule and globus pallidus
Contains primarily medium spiny neurons with GABAergic outputs
Organized somatotopically with connections to sensorimotor cortex
function: Primary component of motor basal ganglia circuits
Critical for initiation and execution of voluntary movements
Involved in motor learning and automatic execution of learned movements
Contributes to timing and sequencing of complex motor actions

74.name: Putamen_R
structure: Right putamen, a rounded structure forming lateral part of the lentiform nucleus
Located lateral to the internal capsule and globus pallidus
Receives topographically organized cortical inputs
Connected to sensorimotor cortex, thalamus, and substantia nigra
function: Essential for regulation of movement and motor control
Involved in motor preparation and execution
Important for procedural learning and habit formation
Contributes to implicit learning of motor sequences

75.name: Pallidum_L
structure: Left globus pallidus, divided into internal (GPi) and external (GPe) segments
Forms medial part of the lentiform nucleus
Contains mainly GABAergic neurons with high firing rates
Major output nucleus of the basal ganglia to thalamus
function: Critical for regulation of voluntary movement
GPe forms part of the indirect pathway inhibiting unwanted movements
GPi serves as primary output conveying basal ganglia information to thalamus
Important for movement initiation and suppression of competing motor programs

76.name: Pallidum_R
structure: Right globus pallidus, divided into internal (GPi) and external (GPe) segments
Forms medial part of the lentiform nucleus
Contains mainly GABAergic projection neurons
Receives input primarily from striatum and subthalamic nucleus
function: Critical for regulation of voluntary movement
Involved in selection and inhibition of motor programs
GPi projects to thalamus forming final output stage of basal ganglia
Important for smooth execution of sequential movements

77.name: Thalamus_L
structure: Left thalamus, an ovoid mass of gray matter in the diencephalon
Composed of multiple nuclei organized into anterior, medial, lateral, and ventral groups
Connected reciprocally with cerebral cortex via thalamocortical and corticothalamic fibers
Forms part of the walls of the third ventricle
function: Serves as major relay station for sensory information to the cortex
Regulates consciousness, sleep, and alertness
Processes and integrates motor information from basal ganglia and cerebellum
Contributes to attention, memory, and language functions

78.name: Thalamus_R
structure: Right thalamus, an ovoid mass of gray matter in the diencephalon
Composed of multiple nuclei with specific functions and connections
Contains specific relay nuclei (LGN, MGN, VPL/VPM) and association nuclei
Connected to virtually all cortical areas via reciprocal projections
function: Gates and modulates sensory information to the cortex
Participates in motor control via ventral anterior and lateral nuclei
Involved in regulation of arousal and consciousness
Contributes to emotional processing via connections with limbic system

79.name: Heschl_L
structure: Left Heschl's gyrus (transverse temporal gyrus) located on the superior temporal plane
First gyrus of the temporal lobe, buried within the lateral sulcus
Contains primary auditory cortex (Brodmann areas 41 and 42)
Organized tonotopically with high frequencies represented medially
function: Processes basic auditory information including frequency, intensity, and timing
Critical for speech perception and phoneme discrimination
Essential for temporal processing of auditory signals
Important for pitch perception and harmonic analysis

80.name: Heschl_R
structure: Right Heschl's gyrus (transverse temporal gyrus) located on the superior temporal plane
First gyrus of the temporal lobe, hidden within the lateral sulcus
Contains primary auditory cortex (Brodmann areas 41 and 42)
Organized tonotopically with frequency-specific neurons
function: Processes basic auditory information from both ears (with contralateral dominance)
Specialized for processing musical elements including pitch and rhythm
Important for environmental sound recognition
Contributes to spatial localization of sounds

81.name: Temporal_Sup_L
structure: Left superior temporal gyrus located on the lateral surface of the temporal lobe
Contains auditory association cortex posterior to Heschl's gyrus
Includes Wernicke's area in its posterior portion
Connected to inferior frontal regions via the arcuate fasciculus
function: Critical for language comprehension and semantic processing
Processes complex auditory information including speech
Important for phonological processing and verbal working memory
Contributes to social cognition through voice and prosody analysis

82.name: Temporal_Sup_R
structure: Right superior temporal gyrus located on the lateral surface of the temporal lobe
Contains auditory association cortex posterior to Heschl's gyrus
Connected to homologous left hemisphere regions via corpus callosum
Rich in connections with multimodal association areas
function: Processes prosodic and emotional aspects of language
Important for music appreciation and processing
Involved in voice recognition and speaker identification
Contributes to auditory attention and environmental sound processing

83.name: Temporal_Pole_Sup_L
structure: Left superior temporal pole forming the anterior tip of the temporal lobe
Contains Brodmann area 38
Connected to limbic structures including amygdala and orbitofrontal cortex
Has rich multimodal connections with sensory association areas
function: Integrates complex auditory and linguistic information
Involved in social cognition and theory of mind
Important for semantic memory and conceptual knowledge
Contributes to narrative comprehension and social context processing

84.name: Temporal_Pole_Sup_R
structure: Right superior temporal pole forming the anterior tip of the temporal lobe
Contains Brodmann area 38
Connected to paralimbic regions and social cognition networks
Rich in connections with orbitofrontal cortex and insula
function: Important for socioemotional processing and empathy
Involved in face recognition and person knowledge
Contributes to processing emotional prosody in speech
Participates in autobiographical memory and personal semantics

85.name: Temporal_Mid_L
structure: Left middle temporal gyrus located on the lateral surface of the temporal lobe
Located between superior and inferior temporal sulci
Contains portions of the visual association cortex posteriorly
Connected to language networks and semantic processing systems
function: Critical for lexical-semantic processing and vocabulary knowledge
Important for processing of word meaning and conceptual knowledge
Involved in sentence comprehension and discourse processing
Contributes to multimodal semantic integration

86.name: Temporal_Mid_R
structure: Right middle temporal gyrus located on the lateral surface of the temporal lobe
Located between superior and inferior temporal sulci
Contains portions of the visual association cortex posteriorly
Connected to attention networks and visual processing streams
function: Involved in processing of complex visual stimuli including biological motion
Contributes to social perception and nonverbal communication
Important for processing metaphorical and abstract concepts
Participates in visual semantic processing and object recognition

87.name: Temporal_Pole_Mid_L
structure: Left middle temporal pole at the anterior extremity of the temporal lobe
Contains anterior portions of Brodmann area 21
Connected to limbic structures and anterior language regions
Forms part of the anterior temporal lobe semantic hub
function: Important for semantic processing and conceptual knowledge
Involved in social semantic processing and person knowledge
Contributes to narrative comprehension and complex language understanding
Participates in processing of unique entities and proper names

88.name: Temporal_Pole_Mid_R
structure: Right middle temporal pole at the anterior extremity of the temporal lobe
Contains anterior portions of Brodmann area 21
Connected to socioemotional processing networks
Rich in connections with orbitofrontal cortex and limbic structures
function: Important for social cognition and emotional processing
Involved in recognition of familiar faces and voices
Contributes to understanding of social contexts and relationships
Participates in processing of emotionally salient autobiographical memories

89.name: Temporal_Inf_L
structure: Left inferior temporal gyrus located on the inferior lateral surface of the temporal lobe
Contains visual association cortex including area V4
Forms part of the ventral visual stream ('what' pathway)
Connected to other temporal regions and fusiform gyrus
function: Critical for visual object recognition and identification
Important for processing of complex visual features and patterns
Involved in reading and visual word form processing
Contributes to category-specific semantic knowledge

90.name: Temporal_Inf_R
structure: Right inferior temporal gyrus located on the inferior lateral surface of the temporal lobe
Contains visual association cortex including area V4
Forms part of the ventral visual stream ('what' pathway)
Connected to other temporal regions and occipitotemporal areas
function: Important for visual object recognition and discrimination
Involved in face processing and visual expertise
Contributes to processing of complex visual patterns
Participates in visual memory encoding and retrieval

91.name: Cerebelum_Crus1_L
structure: Left cerebellar crus I located in the posterior lobe of the cerebellum
Part of the neocerebellum (phylogenetically recent)
Connected primarily to prefrontal and parietal association cortices
Contains high density of Purkinje cells with extensive dendritic arborization
function: Involved in higher cognitive functions including working memory
Contributes to language processing and verbal fluency
Participates in executive functions including planning and cognitive flexibility
Important for timing and sequencing of cognitive operations

92.name: Cerebelum_Crus1_L
structure: Left cerebellar hemisphere crus I of the posterior lobe
Located in the lateral-posterior aspect of the cerebellum
Forms part of the neocerebellum (phylogenetically newest region)
Receives input primarily from the cerebral cortex via pontine nuclei
Projects to the dentate nucleus which connects to thalamus and cerebral cortex
function: Involved in cognitive functions including working memory and executive function
Participates in complex motor planning and coordination
Contributes to language processing networks
Shows activation during tasks requiring timing and sequencing
Implicated in attentional processes and cognitive flexibility

93.name: Cerebelum_Crus1_R
structure: Right cerebellar hemisphere crus I of the posterior lobe
Located in the lateral-posterior aspect of the cerebellum
Forms part of the neocerebellum (phylogenetically newest region)
Receives input primarily from the cerebral cortex via pontine nuclei
Projects to the dentate nucleus which connects to thalamus and cerebral cortex
function: Involved in cognitive functions including spatial processing
Participates in complex motor planning and coordination
Contributes to visuospatial processing networks
Shows activation during tasks requiring timing and sequencing
Implicated in attentional processes and cognitive flexibility

94.name: Cerebelum_Crus2_L
structure: Left cerebellar hemisphere crus II of the posterior lobe
Positioned posterior to crus I in the lateral cerebellar hemisphere
Part of the neocerebellum with extensive corticopontine connections
Contains densely packed Purkinje cells and parallel fibers
Receives climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus
function: Contributes to cognitive processing and emotional regulation
Participates in error detection during movement and learning
Involved in abstract reasoning and cognitive planning
Active during complex cognitive tasks requiring sequencing
Has functional connectivity with prefrontal networks

95.name: Cerebelum_Crus2_R
structure: Right cerebellar hemisphere crus II of the posterior lobe
Positioned posterior to crus I in the lateral cerebellar hemisphere
Part of the neocerebellum with extensive corticopontine connections
Contains densely packed Purkinje cells and parallel fibers
Receives climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus
function: Contributes to cognitive processing and emotional regulation
Participates in error detection during movement and learning
Involved in visuospatial processing and mental imagery
Active during complex cognitive tasks requiring sequencing
Has functional connectivity with prefrontal and parietal networks

96.name: Cerebelum_3_L
structure: Left cerebellar lobule III, part of the anterior lobe
Located in the anterior-medial aspect of the cerebellum
Part of the spinocerebellum (paleocerebellum)
Receives somatosensory input from the spinal cord via spinocerebellar tracts
Projects to the interposed nucleus which connects to the red nucleus and thalamus
function: Involved in coordination of ipsilateral limb movements
Processes proprioceptive information from the left side of the body
Participates in motor learning and adaptation
Contributes to posture and balance regulation
Modulates muscle tone and coordination during movements

97.name: Cerebelum_3_R
structure: Right cerebellar lobule III, part of the anterior lobe
Located in the anterior-medial aspect of the cerebellum
Part of the spinocerebellum (paleocerebellum)
Receives somatosensory input from the spinal cord via spinocerebellar tracts
Projects to the interposed nucleus which connects to the red nucleus and thalamus
function: Involved in coordination of ipsilateral limb movements
Processes proprioceptive information from the right side of the body
Participates in motor learning and adaptation
Contributes to posture and balance regulation
Modulates muscle tone and coordination during movements

98.name: Cerebelum_4_5_L
structure: Left cerebellar lobules IV and V, part of the anterior lobe
Located in the anterior superior aspect of the cerebellum
Part of the spinocerebellum with sensorimotor representations
Receives input from proprioceptors and the motor cortex
Contains somatotopic representation of the body (cerebellar homunculus)
function: Controls coordination of voluntary limb movements on the left side
Integrates sensory information for coordinated movement execution
Involved in predictive control of reaching and grasping
Participates in corrective movements during ongoing motor tasks
Important for motor skill acquisition and consolidation

99.name: Cerebelum_4_5_R
structure: Right cerebellar lobules IV and V, part of the anterior lobe
Located in the anterior superior aspect of the cerebellum
Part of the spinocerebellum with sensorimotor representations
Receives input from proprioceptors and the motor cortex
Contains somatotopic representation of the body (cerebellar homunculus)
function: Controls coordination of voluntary limb movements on the right side
Integrates sensory information for coordinated movement execution
Involved in predictive control of reaching and grasping
Participates in corrective movements during ongoing motor tasks
Important for motor skill acquisition and consolidation

100.name: Cerebelum_6_L
structure: Left cerebellar lobule VI, positioned at the transition between anterior and posterior lobes
Located at the superior surface of the cerebellum
Contains dense granule cell layer and elaborate Purkinje cell dendritic trees
Receives input from both motor and association cortices via pontine nuclei
Projects primarily to the dentate nucleus
function: Plays a dual role in both motor and cognitive function
Involved in oculomotor control and saccadic eye movements
Participates in spatial processing and motor imagery
Contributes to language processing networks in the left hemisphere
Activated during procedural learning and skilled movement execution

101.name: Cerebelum_6_R
structure: Right cerebellar lobule VI, positioned at the transition between anterior and posterior lobes
Located at the superior surface of the cerebellum
Contains dense granule cell layer and elaborate Purkinje cell dendritic trees
Receives input from both motor and association cortices via pontine nuclei
Projects primarily to the dentate nucleus
function: Plays a dual role in both motor and cognitive function
Involved in oculomotor control and saccadic eye movements
Participates in spatial processing and motor imagery
Contributes to visuospatial processing networks
Activated during procedural learning and skilled movement execution

102.name: Cerebelum_7b_L
structure: Left cerebellar lobule VIIB, part of the posterior lobe
Located in the inferior posterior aspect of the cerebellum
Part of the neocerebellum with extensive connections to association cortices
Receives input primarily from prefrontal and parietal cortices via pontine nuclei
Projects to the dentate and interposed nuclei
function: Involved in higher-order cognitive functions
Participates in executive function and working memory processes
Contributes to error detection and performance monitoring
Active during complex cognitive tasks requiring sequencing
Plays a role in attentional shifting and cognitive flexibility

103.name: Cerebelum_7b_R
structure: Right cerebellar lobule VIIB, part of the posterior lobe
Located in the inferior posterior aspect of the cerebellum
Part of the neocerebellum with extensive connections to association cortices
Receives input primarily from prefrontal and parietal cortices via pontine nuclei
Projects to the dentate and interposed nuclei
function: Involved in higher-order cognitive functions
Participates in executive function and working memory processes
Contributes to error detection and performance monitoring
Active during complex cognitive tasks requiring visuospatial processing
Plays a role in attentional shifting and cognitive flexibility

104.name: Cerebelum_8_L
structure: Left cerebellar lobule VIII, part of the posterior lobe
Located in the posterior-inferior aspect of the cerebellum
Contains secondary somatosensory representations
Receives input from both sensorimotor and association cortices
Projects primarily to the interposed and dentate nuclei
function: Involved in sensorimotor coordination of complex movements
Participates in execution and timing of sequential movements
Contributes to procedural learning and skill acquisition
Has functional connectivity with sensorimotor networks
Activated during tasks requiring precise timing and coordination

105.name: Cerebelum_8_R
structure: Right cerebellar lobule VIII, part of the posterior lobe
Located in the posterior-inferior aspect of the cerebellum
Contains secondary somatosensory representations
Receives input from both sensorimotor and association cortices
Projects primarily to the interposed and dentate nuclei
function: Involved in sensorimotor coordination of complex movements
Participates in execution and timing of sequential movements
Contributes to procedural learning and skill acquisition
Has functional connectivity with sensorimotor networks
Activated during tasks requiring precise timing and coordination

106.name: Cerebelum_9_L
structure: Left cerebellar lobule IX (uvula), part of the posterior lobe
Located in the posterior-inferior vermis and adjacent hemisphere
Part of the vestibulocerebellum (archicerebellum)
Receives vestibular input and visual motion information
Projects to the fastigial and vestibular nuclei
function: Processes vestibular and visual information for balance control
Participates in coordination of eye movements with head and body motion
Involved in spatial orientation and navigation
Contributes to autonomic regulation including cardiovascular control
Plays a role in cerebellar-mediated reflexes

107.name: Cerebelum_9_R
structure: Right cerebellar lobule IX (uvula), part of the posterior lobe
Located in the posterior-inferior vermis and adjacent hemisphere
Part of the vestibulocerebellum (archicerebellum)
Receives vestibular input and visual motion information
Projects to the fastigial and vestibular nuclei
function: Processes vestibular and visual information for balance control
Participates in coordination of eye movements with head and body motion
Involved in spatial orientation and navigation
Contributes to autonomic regulation including cardiovascular control
Plays a role in cerebellar-mediated reflexes

108.name: Cerebelum_10_L
structure: Left cerebellar lobule X (flocculus), part of the flocculonodular lobe
Located at the most inferior aspect of the cerebellum
Oldest part of the cerebellum phylogenetically (archicerebellum)
Receives direct vestibular input via mossy fibers
Projects to the vestibular nuclei in the brainstem
function: Critical for vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) adaptation
Maintains gaze stability during head movements
Integrates vestibular and visual information for balance
Involved in learning of compensatory eye movements
Dysfunction results in nystagmus and balance disorders

109.name: Cerebelum_10_R
structure: Right cerebellar lobule X (flocculus), part of the flocculonodular lobe
Located at the most inferior aspect of the cerebellum
Oldest part of the cerebellum phylogenetically (archicerebellum)
Receives direct vestibular input via mossy fibers
Projects to the vestibular nuclei in the brainstem
function: Critical for vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) adaptation
Maintains gaze stability during head movements
Integrates vestibular and visual information for balance
Involved in learning of compensatory eye movements
Dysfunction results in nystagmus and balance disorders

110.name: Vermis_1_2
structure: Cerebellar vermis lobules I and II (lingula), midline structure of anterior lobe
Most superior and anterior part of the vermis
Part of the spinocerebellum with primarily motor functions
Receives input from vestibular nuclei and spinal cord
Projects primarily to the fastigial nucleus
function: Involved in postural control and balance
Regulates trunk and proximal limb movements
Coordinates midline body movements
Participates in autonomic functions including respiratory control
Lesions may result in truncal ataxia and gait disturbances

111.name: Vermis_3
structure: Cerebellar vermis lobule III (central lobule), midline structure of anterior lobe
Located between vermis lobules II and IV
Part of the spinocerebellum with extensive proprioceptive input
Contains Purkinje cells projecting primarily to fastigial nucleus
Receives input from spinocerebellar tracts
function: Controls axial and proximal limb movements
Contributes to postural stability during stance and gait
Involved in coordination of bilateral movements
Integrates proprioceptive information for movement control
Dysfunction contributes to midline cerebellar syndromes

112.name: Vermis_4_5
structure: Cerebellar vermis lobules IV and V (culmen), midline structures of anterior lobe
Centrally located in the superior aspect of the vermis
Receives input from motor cortex via cortico-pontine-cerebellar pathway
Contains somatotopic representation of body parts
Projects primarily to fastigial nucleus
function: Coordinates voluntary movements of the extremities
Contributes to gait control and bilateral coordination
Involved in motor planning and execution
Participates in feed-forward control of movement
Damage results in ataxia and decomposition of movement

113.name: Vermis_6
structure: Cerebellar vermis lobule VI (declive), midline structure at border of anterior and posterior lobes
Located in central superior vermis
Receives input from motor and premotor cortices
Contains somatotopic representation with emphasis on distal limbs
Projects to fastigial and interposed nuclei
function: Involved in coordination of skilled voluntary movements
Participates in saccadic and smooth pursuit eye movements
Contributes to spatial aspects of movement planning
Active during complex motor sequence learning
Implicated in attention to action and motor imagery

114.name: Vermis_7
structure: Cerebellar vermis lobule VII (folium and tuber), midline structure of posterior lobe
Comprises posterior superior aspect of vermis
Receives input from association cortices via pontine nuclei
Contains high density of Purkinje cells projecting to fastigial nucleus
Has extensive connections with limbic structures
function: Involved in cognitive and emotional processing
Contributes to executive functions and working memory
Participates in visually guided movement planning
Important for cerebellar contributions to language processing
Implicated in cerebellar cognitive affective syndrome when damaged

115.name: Vermis_8
structure: Cerebellar vermis lobule VIII (pyramis), midline structure of posterior lobe
Located in posterior inferior vermis
Receives input from sensorimotor cortices
Contains secondary representation of extremities
Projects primarily to fastigial and interposed nuclei
function: Coordinates complex multi-joint movements
Involved in timing and sequencing of motor actions
Participates in motor adaptation and error correction
Contributes to coordination of lower limb movements
Important for gait coordination and stability

116.name: Vermis_9
structure: Cerebellar vermis lobule IX (uvula), midline structure of posterior lobe
Located in most posterior inferior vermis
Part of the vestibulocerebellum
Receives vestibular and visual inputs
Projects to fastigial and vestibular nuclei
function: Crucial for balance and spatial orientation
Integrates vestibular signals for postural control
Involved in adaptation of vestibulo-ocular reflexes
Contributes to autonomic regulation including cardiovascular control
Lesions can result in truncal ataxia and disturbances in equilibrium

117.name: Vermis_10
structure: Cerebellar vermis lobule X (nodulus), most inferior midline structure
Part of the flocculonodular lobe (archicerebellum)
Phylogenetically oldest part of the vermis
Receives direct vestibular afferents
Projects primarily to vestibular nuclei
function: Critical for vestibular processing and balance
Regulates vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal reflexes
Contributes to spatial orientation in three-dimensional space
Important for adaptation to altered gravity conditions
Lesions result in severe equilibrium disturbances and nystagmus
